displaytitle: More Machine Than Man, Twisted and Evil, from the series, Strike the Empire Back
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund

titles.title: More Machine Than Man, Twisted and Evil, from the series, Strike the Empire Back

texts.textentryhtml: Michael Rakowitz, the artist, Chicago, Illinois, consigned to; [Lombard- Fried Projects LLC, New York, New York], sold; to Princeton University Art Museum, 2009.
texts.remarks: as per invoice in curatorial file. AP.

texts.textentryhtml:
Rakowitz is deeply invested in the cultural, political, and economic conditions of pre- and postwar Iraq. This drawing belongs to a 2009 series that explores the myths and fantasies that shaped Saddam Hussein’s public image, among them the Star Wars film trilogy, which provided the model for everything from Iraqi monuments to military uniforms and weapons.

Similar in format to a comic strip, the work intersperses scenes drawn from cinema, historical photographs, and the artist’s own imagination. Two scenes depict a battle in Mosul in 2003, during which Saddam’s sons, Uday and Qusay, were killed by American soldiers. One is sampled from Star Wars. The final two pictures represent a group of Iraqi officials, among them Saddam and Uday, watching Star Wars in a private theatre in 1980, shortly before Iraq went to war with Iran. In Rakowitz’s drawing, fact and fiction collide, providing insight into the mechanics of power in an age of television, film, and spectacle.

Iraqi American artist Michael Rakowitz addresses the cultural, political, and economic conditions of pre- and postwar Iraq. His work often assumes unconventional forms, such as the fully functioning store he opened in Brooklyn in 2006 from which he sold Iraqi goods and foodstuffs. Perhaps his most poignant project to date involves reconstructing all of the 15,000 objects looted from Baghdad’s National Museum in April 2003. As these examples suggest, Rakowitz’s work is simultaneously symbolic and ameliorative, critical and practical. The drawing seen here belongs to Strike the Empire Back, a 2009 series that explores the myths, illusions, and movies from which Saddam Hussein crafted a public image.

bibliography.boilertext: Ann Coxon and Rachel Taylor, Strike the empire back: episode IV: the lord, the homeland, the leader, (London: Tate Modern, 2010).
bibliography.citation: Ann Coxon and Rachel Taylor, Strike the empire back: episode IV: the lord, the homeland, the leader, (London: Tate Modern, 2010).
